instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG? PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG is a power rail that powers the GPU in an S0 working state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
No visible damage.
Liquid, no.


Starts and chimes (nice long dong).
No image to internal screen or external monitor.
Backlight working, lights up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: What if you remove the SSD? Will it go to missing OS icon after a few minutes?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="arghhh, post: 11113"]What if you remove the SSD? Will it go to missing OS icon after a few minutes?[/QUOTE]

Yeah, that was the first thing I tried was to remove SSD, plug external drive (my test drive) and hold alt key for boot options... Nothing.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is 0.85V is that right? I don't have a working board to test

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="arghhh, post: 11113"]What if you remove the SSD? Will it go to missing OS icon after a few minutes?[/QUOTE]

I have seen bad SSDs cause blank screen and would not boot from anything while the drive was on the board. I assume then a similar problem on the board could do the same.
I notice that the external drive LED is not flashing as it does on all good machines I have plugged it into.

I have be through a laborious process and tested everything around GFX / GPU power and everything reads OK.... Completely at a loss! No fucking idea where to go from here.

Any guidance please?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: If you have <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL>, then remove L9330 and L9360 and then inject 1v onto <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG</SIGNAL> with a power supply and see if it works, if not then fucked.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: GPU Vcore at 8.5V seems unlikely, check again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11130"]GPU Vcore at 8.5V seems unlikely, check again.[/QUOTE]

:) heh, yes of course. 0.856V
Changed it above too

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: If backlight work a bad LCD is the first suspect.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11132"]If backlight work a bad LCD is the first suspect.[/QUOTE]

Tried unplugging screen already and connecting to internal monitor.
If not screen and not connector, maybe mux?... BUT...

The machine is not actually booting as the keyboard does not light up, there is no sound when entering the wrong password after leaving the machine to boot for 5 minutes.
Controller on the SSD is uncomfortably hot to touch, can't keep fingers on it. If you wanted to test for a fault on the SSD circuit where would you start?

At this point I would like to try and rule that out as I think it could be causing blank screen same as as bad SSD can do.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: SSD controller gets hot, normal. Disconnect everything from the board and test with a known good LCD assembly.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
Fresh new screen, no different.
Tried eternal monitor again, no different.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: Can you do a PRAM reset?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11181"]Can you do a PRAM reset?[/QUOTE]

Oh FFS... I don't even need to say it do I?
I swear it didn't work before.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Image
threads.message: So we can call this fixed?

Thank you for your time.
